title: Salmon producer Tassal joins legal action over Macquarie Harbour
text:
Salmon producer Tassal joins Macquarie Harbour legal action to protect interests Updated February 22, 2017 17:12:43 Map: TAS 
Australia's largest salmon company Tassal has announced it is joining the legal action taken by its main competitor Huon Aquaculture against Tasmania's Environment Protection Authority (EPA) to protect it interests. 
Tassal, along with fellow producer Petuna, initially ruled out joining the proceedings but has informed the stock exchange today it has decided to join the action. 
It also informed the ASX it may halve the amount of salmon it farms in the harbour. 
Huon is arguing the EPA's decision to allow the farming of 14,000 tonnes of salmon from the harbour is too high. 
Tassal chief executive Mark Ryan told a meeting of shareholders today his company was joining the action to protect its rights. 
"We're not joining with Huon, we're joining the action," Mr Ryan said. 
"It would be fair to say we support the regulator, all we're saying is we've joined the action, not that we've joined with Huon. 
"I don't quite understand why they've [ Huon] done what they've done, we need to be a part of the proceedings so we can determine our own position on it." 
Mr Ryan said Tassal would "own" the part it has played in environmental degradation in the harbour. 
"The last thing we're going to do is go in there and not own and be accountable for what's happened there." 
He said Macquarie Harbour had "presented environmental challenges that were difficult to predict". 
"That doesn't mean the harbour is unsustainable," he said. 
"We definitely own our part in the current position in Macquarie Harbour, we know the Franklin site will recover, we're committed to getting it back to compliance." 
The Tasmanian Government said it would "vigorously" defend itself in legal action over its handling of Macquarie Harbour. Salmon producers report strong growth 
The move by Tassal to join the legal action comes as Tasmanian salmon producers report increased profits thanks to improved weather conditions and a strong salmon price. 
Huon posted a net profit after tax of $31.5 million for the first half of this financial year compared to a loss of $1.3 million at the same time last year. 
In a letter to investors, the company said more favourable weather patterns, higher prices and better feed performance led to the improvement. 
"It is particularly gratifying after the challenges experienced in financial year 2016 to report such a strong result for the first half of 2017," managing director Peter Bender said. 
"We are now firmly back on track and able to focus our energies on continuing to build a resilient and sustainable business." 
Huon said its sales to the Australian retail market had doubled. 
The company's harvest tonnage was down 24 per cent on last year but said that was because of a decision to bring forward harvest in the first half of 2016 in anticipation of forecast El Nino conditions.
